structure: Check website

title: MSc Structural Engineering
summary: The MSc in Structural Engineering at the University of Bristol is a one-year, full-time program designed to equip students with industry-relevant skills. It offers three specialized pathways: Asset Management and Digital Transformation, Composite Materials and Sustainable Design, and Earthquake Engineering, preparing graduates for impactful careers in the field. The program emphasizes advanced engineering skills, real-world applications, and collaboration with industry experts.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or international equivalent in relevant fields such as Civil/Structural Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, or Mathematics. Additional qualifications may be considered.
structure: The program spans 12 months, focusing on advanced structural analysis, specialized technical pathways, applied professional experience through field trips, and culminates in a RIBA Stage 2 design project.

title: MSc Sustainable Engineering
summary: The MSc in Sustainable Engineering at the University of Bristol is a one-year taught programme designed for graduates to deepen their knowledge in sustainability within engineering. It combines foundational skills with specialisms in Civil Engineering, Renewable Energy, or Product Development. The programme culminates in a group-based dissertation, reflecting real-life engineering collaboration.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or international equivalent in an Engineering or Engineering-related subject is required. Applications from other Science subjects may be considered on a case-by-case basis. English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: The programme includes four core units focusing on Systems, Design, Entrepreneurship and Enterprise, and Research Skills, along with two pathway-specific units for further specialization.

title: MSc Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL)
summary: The MSc in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) is designed for teachers and TESOL professionals, providing a flexible learning environment to reflect on professional practice and engage with theoretical frameworks. Participants can also gain a Cambridge English CELTA certificate alongside their MSc. The program emphasizes the importance of professional experience and prepares graduates for various roles in education and policy.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or an international equivalent in any discipline is required. If currently completing a degree, interim grades may be considered for an aspirational offer.
structure: The program can be completed in one year full-time or two to three years part-time, with a focus on professional practice and theoretical frameworks.

title: MSc Technology Innovation and Entrepreneurship
summary: The MSc in Technology Innovation and Entrepreneurship at the University of Bristol is designed for individuals with a technical background who aspire to become leaders and founders in the tech industry. The program emphasizes hands-on learning through collaborative projects, equipping students with the skills to launch successful ventures and lead technology-driven enterprises. Students will learn to harness AI strategically and gain practical experience in taking technology from concept to market.
requirements: Typically, an upper second class honours degree or international equivalent in a technology discipline is required. Other backgrounds may be considered with 2 years of relevant professional experience. Additional qualifications or work experience may strengthen your application.
structure: The program is structured over one year, divided into three phases: Term 1 focuses on core skills of innovation, Term 2 involves applying technical expertise in real-world scenarios, and the summer culminates in launching a tech venture.
careers: Designers and Strategists in global firms

title: MSc Translational Cardiovascular Medicine
summary: The MSc in Translational Cardiovascular Medicine at the University of Bristol focuses on developing knowledge and critical awareness of cardiovascular research and medicine. It emphasizes the application of laboratory research to clinical practice, preparing students for careers in healthcare and research. The program includes a research project and offers both on-campus and online learning options.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or an international equivalent in a biological, health, or medicine-related science subject is required. Relevant work experience or a postgraduate qualification may also be considered.
structure: The MSc program consists of 6 taught units and a research project, with options for full-time or part-time study.

title: MSc Translational Cardiovascular Medicine (Online)
summary: The MSc in Translational Cardiovascular Medicine aims to develop students' interest in cardiovascular research and medicine, providing enhanced knowledge of current approaches and emerging research. The program emphasizes the application of laboratory research to clinical interventions, fostering critical analysis of existing practices. It is designed for a diverse range of students, including biomedical scientists and clinicians, and offers both online and on-campus study options.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or international equivalent in a biological, health, or medicine-related science subject is required. Relevant work experience or a postgraduate qualification may also be considered.
structure: The MSc program consists of six taught units and a research project, with options for full-time or part-time study.

title: MSc Water and Environmental Management
summary: The MSc in Water and Environmental Management at the University of Bristol prepares students to tackle local and global water and environmental challenges by equipping them with essential technical and management skills. The program combines academic and practical training, allowing students to choose from a range of optional units that balance quantitative and qualitative skills. Students will engage in research and practical applications, culminating in a dissertation supervised by expert tutors.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or an international equivalent in relevant fields such as Engineering, Science, Computing, Maths, Geography, Environmental Management, Agriculture, or Economics is required. Relevant work experience or a postgraduate qualification may also be considered.
structure: The program includes core units that cover fundamental principles of water and environmental management, advanced units focusing on global water resource management, and optional units that enhance skills in data analysis and systems thinking. Students will also develop research skills for their dissertation.

title: MSc Wireless Communications and Signal Processing
summary: The MSc in Wireless Communications and Signal Processing at the University of Bristol prepares students for high-impact careers in 5G/6G networks, IoT, and satellite communications. The program combines advanced wireless communication theories with practical skills and includes a substantial capstone project to apply learning to real-world challenges. Students benefit from the expertise of renowned research groups and develop competencies sought by leading employers.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or international equivalent in relevant fields such as Communications Engineering, Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, or related disciplines. Additional qualifications may strengthen applications with slightly lower grades.
structure: The program comprises six core units followed by a substantial capstone project that starts after the second term and completes during the summer.

title: Music
summary: The University of Bristol's Department of Music offers PhD, MMus, and MPhil programs focusing on research excellence in composition and musicology. Students engage in diverse research projects, exploring areas such as acoustic and electro-acoustic music, Western and non-Western traditions, and various musicological topics. The programs emphasize both independent research and the option to audit relevant master's units.

requirements.MPhil (Musicology): Upper second-class degree or international equivalent.
requirements.MPhil (Composition): Upper second-class degree or international equivalent, plus a portfolio of representative compositions.
requirements.MMus (Composition): Upper second-class degree or international equivalent, plus a portfolio of representative compositions and evidence of professional accomplishment.
requirements.PhD (Musicology): Master's qualification or working towards one, or international equivalent; exceptional cases may be considered.
requirements.PhD (Composition or Musicology): Master's qualification or working towards one, or international equivalent; exceptional cases may be considered.

structure.MPhil: One-year full-time research degree culminating in a portfolio or dissertation.
structure.MMus: Two-year full-time research degree culminating in a portfolio.
structure.PhD: Three to four years research project culminating in a portfolio or thesis.

title: Oral and Dental Sciences
summary: The Oral and Dental Sciences program at the University of Bristol combines laboratory-based and clinically-applied research, fostering collaboration among research groups. It offers postgraduate students opportunities to engage in broad research communities within the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences and the Bristol Doctoral College, supported by various funding sources.
requirements: An upper second class honours degree (or international equivalent) or a master's degree with a lower second class honours degree (or international equivalent) in a relevant subject. English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: MScR: up to two years full-time; up to four years part-time. PhD: up to four years full-time; up to eight years part-time.

title: PG Certificate (Postgraduate Certificate) Clinical Conscious Sedation and Anxiety Management
summary: The PG Certificate in Clinical Conscious Sedation and Anxiety Management is designed for dental practitioners to enhance their skills in conscious sedation and anxiety management. The program includes distance learning modules, supervised clinical placements, and training in intravenous sedation. Students will gain practical experience and theoretical knowledge, culminating in the opportunity to become accredited sedation providers.
requirements: Typically, a Bachelor of Dental Surgery or an equivalent UK General Dental Council-registrable dental qualification is required, along with at least one year of demonstrable postgraduate clinical experience. Applicants should be experienced general dental practitioners with confidence in delivering routine oral surgery.
structure: The program is modular and divided into three units, focusing on clinical skills, anxiety management, and sedation techniques.
careers: Dental practitioners specializing in conscious sedation

title: PG Certificate (Postgraduate Certificate) Clinical Neuropsychology Practice
summary: The PG Certificate in Clinical Neuropsychology Practice at the University of Bristol is designed to enhance the skills of clinicians in clinical neuropsychology, supporting their entry onto the British Psychological Society's Specialist Register of Clinical Neuropsychologists. The program is delivered in partnership with North Bristol NHS Trust and includes a clinical practice dissertation that requires the submission of a portfolio demonstrating required competencies. It is primarily online, allowing flexibility for students.
requirements: Applicants typically need to be registered with the HCPC as a practitioner in Clinical, Educational, or Counselling psychology, and must have the BPS qualification in Clinical Neuropsychology knowledge component certificate. They should also demonstrate how they meet the Research Competencies requirement for the program.
structure: The certificate consists of a clinical practice dissertation culminating in a portfolio of practice that includes six clinical cases, satisfactory performance in a viva, and evidence of clinical practice and supervision.

title: PG Certificate (Postgraduate Certificate) Clinical Oral Surgery
summary: The PG Certificate in Clinical Oral Surgery at the University of Bristol aims to enhance students' clinical skills and knowledge in oral surgery. The program includes study days, clinical teaching, and hands-on surgery under specialist supervision. Students can also combine this program with a Postgraduate Certificate in Clinical Conscious Sedation and Anxiety Management.
fees: Home: £12,800 per year, Overseas: £17,800 per year
requirements: Typically requires a Bachelor of Dental Surgery or an equivalent UK General Dental Council-registrable dental qualification. Must hold full or temporary registration with the UK General Dental Council.
structure: The program consists of 3 units that make up the PG Certificate in Clinical Oral Surgery.

title: PG Certificate (Postgraduate Certificate) Clinical Perfusion Science
summary: The PG Certificate in Clinical Perfusion Science is a blended learning programme designed for Limited Registrant clinical perfusion scientists in Great Britain or Ireland. It provides high-quality education focused on adult and paediatric perfusion principles, equipping students with essential skills for employment in the field. The course includes academic training, practical skills, and research methodologies relevant to perfusion science.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or an international equivalent in a science or medicine-related subject is required. Applicants must have secured a Limited Registrant post at an accredited centre in Great Britain or Ireland.
structure: The programme consists of four taught units, including work-based clinical practice and assessment, delivered through blended learning with in-person teaching during four intensive study weeks in Bristol.

title: PG Diploma (Postgraduate Diploma) Applied Neuropsychology
summary: The PG Diploma in Applied Neuropsychology at the University of Bristol explores the connection between brain function and cognitive/emotional behavior, focusing on clinical neuropsychology. The program covers neuropsychological disorders, assessment principles, and rehabilitation techniques, delivered in partnership with North Bristol NHS Trust. It prepares students for careers in research, clinical positions, or further training in psychology.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or equivalent in Psychology or a closely related discipline is required. For joint degrees, at least half of the content must be in psychology with a minimum score of 60% in relevant modules.
structure: The program consists of five taught units covering applied clinical neuropsychology, issues in clinical neuropsychology, theoretical neuropsychology, neurorehabilitation, and evidence-based neuropsychology.

title: PG Diploma (Postgraduate Diploma) Applied Neuropsychology (Online)
summary: The PG Diploma in Applied Neuropsychology at the University of Bristol focuses on the intersection of biological, psychological, and social aspects of human behavior, emphasizing clinical neuropsychology. Students will learn about neuropsychological disorders, assessment principles, and rehabilitation techniques, delivered by practicing clinicians. The program is designed for those pursuing research careers, professional positions, or further clinical training.
requirements: Typically, an upper second-class honours degree or equivalent in Psychology or a closely related discipline is required. If studied as a joint degree, at least half of the content must be in psychology with a minimum score of 60% overall in psychology modules.
structure: The program consists of five taught units covering applied clinical neuropsychology, issues in clinical neuropsychology, theoretical neuropsychology, neurorehabilitation, and evidence-based neuropsychology with case studies.

title: PG Diploma (Postgraduate Diploma) Clinical Neuropsychology
summary: The PG Diploma in Clinical Neuropsychology at the University of Bristol is a BPS accredited program designed to enhance clinicians' skills in clinical neuropsychology. It supports entry onto the Specialist Register of Clinical Neuropsychologists (SRCN) and offers both adult and paediatric knowledge components. The program is primarily online, with optional in-person attendance, and emphasizes a biopsychosocial approach to neuropsychological research and practice.
requirements: Typically, applicants need to be registered with the Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC) as a practitioner in 'Clinical' or 'Counselling'. Those with 'Forensic' or 'Health' specialisms will be considered on a case-by-case basis. Applicants must also demonstrate Generic Competencies in Clinical Neuropsychology if they have a 'Counselling' specialism.
structure: The program consists of five taught units covering Applied Clinical Neuropsychology, Issues in Clinical Neuropsychology, Theoretical Neuropsychology, Neurorehabilitation, and Evidence Based Neuropsychology.

title: PG Diploma (Postgraduate Diploma) Orthodontic Therapy
summary: The PG Diploma in Orthodontic Therapy at the University of Bristol is designed for registered Dental Care Professionals with relevant orthodontic experience. The program equips students with the skills and knowledge necessary to work as competent Orthodontic Therapists, allowing them to register with the General Dental Council (GDC). Students will benefit from a combination of theoretical learning and practical clinical experience under supervision.
requirements: Candidates must hold a General Dental Council (GDC) registerable DCP qualification and current GDC registration. A UK-based clinical training practice providing a minimum of 23 hours a week of chairside direct clinical experience is required. Desirable qualifications include two or more Post-Registration qualifications in relevant fields.
structure: The program lasts one year, starting with intensive lectures and practical sessions in the first month, followed by clinical practice under supervision. Monthly study days enhance understanding of orthodontic mechanics and treatment delivery.

title: PG Diploma (Postgraduate Diploma) Theoretical and Practical Clinical Neuropsychology
summary: The PG Diploma in Theoretical and Practical Clinical Neuropsychology at the University of Bristol is designed for clinicians to enhance their skills in clinical neuropsychology and support entry onto the BPS Specialist Register of Clinical Neuropsychologists (SRCN). The program combines theoretical knowledge with practical experience, requiring students to secure employment in a neuropsychology service during their studies. It is largely delivered online, with a focus on various neuropsychological disorders and assessment principles.
requirements: Typically, applicants need to be registered as a Clinical Psychologist with the HCPC and studying or have studied at an approved degree from a collaborating institution. They must pass an online entrance assessment and provide evidence of a minimum of six months' practice experience.
structure: The program consists of four taught units and a Clinical Practice Portfolio, covering issues in clinical neuropsychology, theoretical neuropsychology, neurorehabilitation, and evidence-based neuropsychology.

title: PGCE Education (Secondary)
summary: The PGCE Education (Secondary) program at the University of Bristol is a one-year course designed to train teachers across various secondary subjects, leading to a postgraduate qualification (PGCE) and qualified teacher status (QTS). Students will gain practical experience through placements in contrasting schools, including a primary school and a special school, while also receiving academic support and mentorship. The program emphasizes innovative teaching practices and strong partnerships with local schools.
requirements: Applicants must have at least GCSE or equivalent in English and Mathematics at grade C or 4, and a degree (2:2 or above) in a relevant subject. Equivalence tests for GCSEs are considered only in exceptional circumstances.
structure: The program includes four major components: Curriculum Studies, Educational and Professional Studies, Intensive Training and Practice (ITAP), and School Experience placements, all designed to equip students with essential teaching skills.

title: Philosophy
summary: The Philosophy program at the University of Bristol offers MPhil and PhD degrees, focusing on high-quality research in areas such as logic, philosophy of science, ethics, and metaphysics. The department is known for its collaborative seminar programs and research initiatives, including the Centre for Science and Philosophy. Students can engage in independent research culminating in a dissertation or thesis, with opportunities for teaching and auditing courses.

requirements.MPhil: An upper second-class degree (or international equivalent) and evidence of readiness for research.
requirements.PhD: A master's qualification or working towards one, or a first-class undergraduate degree (or international equivalent) for exceptional cases.

structure: MPhil is a one-year full-time research degree culminating in a 25,000-word dissertation. PhD involves a research project over three to four years, culminating in an 80,000-word thesis, with options to audit taught units and potential teaching opportunities from the second year.

title: Physics
summary: The School of Physics at the University of Bristol offers PhD and MSc by research programs in a world-class research environment, ranked 5th in the UK. Students engage in diverse research themes, benefit from strong industry connections, and receive support for professional development. The program emphasizes community building, skills training, and opportunities for teaching roles.

requirements.MScR: A first-class or upper second-class honours degree (or international equivalent) in physics or a closely related subject.
requirements.PhD: A minimum of an upper second-class MSci honours degree in physics or a relevant related discipline, or a postgraduate MSc or international equivalent. Lower second-class MSci or first/upper second-class BSc degrees may be considered with demonstrated research potential.

structure: MScR: up to two years full-time; up to four years part-time. PhD: up to four years full-time; up to eight years part-time.

title: Physiology, Pharmacology and Neuroscience
summary: The School of Physiology, Pharmacology and Neuroscience at the University of Bristol offers PhD and MSc by research programs with a strong emphasis on research excellence in cardiovascular biology, neuroscience, and cell signaling. Students engage in a vibrant research environment, receiving extensive training and support to excel in their studies. The school is committed to fostering the next generation of scientists through diverse research opportunities and collaborations.
requirements: A first or upper second-class honours degree (or international equivalent) in a biomedical science discipline is required for entry to the PhD programme. MSc by research applications may be considered from candidates with a lower second-class degree.
structure: The program includes a focus on key themes such as Cardiovascular and Cell Signaling and Neuroscience, with students working on diverse research projects under the guidance of potential supervisors.

title: Politics
summary: The PhD in Politics at the University of Bristol offers an opportunity to conduct advanced political research within an interdisciplinary environment. Students will engage with internationally renowned scholars and explore key themes such as critical security, political economy, and social inequalities. The program emphasizes rigorous research that is relevant to contemporary political issues and aims to produce work that advances theory and knowledge.
requirements: An upper second-class undergraduate honours degree (or equivalent) and normally a merit at MSc/MA level (or equivalent). English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: The program duration is up to four years full-time or eight years part-time, with a focus on independent research guided by two supervisors.

title: Population Health Sciences
summary: The Population Health Sciences program at the University of Bristol offers multidisciplinary research opportunities in areas such as epidemiology, health services research, and public health. Students can pursue a PhD, MD, or MSc by research, engaging in extensive national and international collaborations. The department aims to attract graduates from various disciplines to contribute to impactful health research.
requirements: An upper second-class honours degree (or international equivalent) or a lower second-class honours degree (or international equivalent) with a master's degree in a relevant subject. For MD registration, an MBChB is required. Applicants must identify two potential supervisors.
structure: MScR: up to two years full-time; PhD: up to four years full-time; MD: up to five years full-time. PhD by Publication: up to one year, full or part-time.

title: Practice-Oriented Artificial Intelligence
summary: The Practice-Oriented Artificial Intelligence PhD program at the University of Bristol focuses on bridging complex problem domains with AI algorithms and techniques. It aims to develop flexible AI experts who can adapt to various domains throughout their careers. The program combines a foundation year of training with three years of PhD research, emphasizing transferable skills and societal impact.
requirements: Applicants must hold a minimum of an upper-second class honours degree (or international equivalent) in a relevant discipline, preferably with a first class degree in engineering or science and strong programming skills. Prior knowledge of contemporary AI techniques is also required.
structure: The program consists of a Foundation Year with modules such as Practice Projects, Foundations of Practice-Oriented AI, and a Summer Project, followed by three years of PhD study and research.

title: Psychology
summary: The Psychology program at the University of Bristol offers PhD and MSc by research opportunities, focusing on human behavior and interdisciplinary research. Students will engage with a vibrant postgraduate community and receive cutting-edge training in various areas, including cognitive science and health interventions. The program emphasizes the importance of research culture and aims to maintain the university's international research reputation.
requirements: A first or upper second-class honours degree (or international equivalent) in psychology or a related discipline is required for entry to the PhD and MSc by research programmes. English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: MScR: up to two years full-time; up to four years part-time. PhD: up to four years full-time; up to eight years part-time.

title: Quantum Information Science and Technologies
summary: The Quantum Information Science & Technologies (QIST) CDT offers a unique postgraduate training program aimed at developing the next generation of quantum scientists and engineers. It combines fundamental and applied research to address societal challenges through advanced computation, sensing, and communications. The program includes cutting-edge training in quantum information and technologies, entrepreneurship, and project management, allowing students to design their own PhD projects after an immersive first year.
requirements: An upper second-class degree (or international equivalent) in physics, electrical engineering, computer science, maths, chemistry, or other relevant physical sciences. English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: Year 1 is a cohort-based training program with modules from the University of Bristol and the University of Sussex, including either one 6-month independent research project or two 3-month exploratory projects. Years 2-4 focus on the research phase leading to the PhD degree.
careers: Roles in the quantum technologies industry

title: Religion and Theology
summary: The Religion and Theology program at the University of Bristol offers MPhil and PhD degrees, focusing on innovative research in various religious traditions and philosophical approaches. Students engage in a vibrant academic community, with opportunities for collaboration and skill development in preparation for academic and professional careers. The program emphasizes interdisciplinary research and provides a supportive environment for postgraduate study.

requirements.MPhil: An upper second-class degree (or international equivalent).
requirements.PhD: A master's qualification or working towards one, or international equivalent. Exceptional cases may be considered for first-class undergraduate degree holders.

structure: MPhil: one year full-time with a 25,000-word dissertation. PhD: up to four years full-time culminating in an 80,000-word thesis, with options to audit taught units and potential teaching opportunities from the second year.
careers: Academics in secondary and higher education

title: Russian
summary: The PhD and MPhil programs in Russian at the University of Bristol focus on a wide range of research areas including Russian literature, intellectual history, film, and cultural studies. The department boasts a strong research culture and encourages postgraduate students to engage in significant research projects. Students can benefit from a supportive community and have opportunities to audit taught units or teach in their second year.
requirements: MPhil: An upper second-class degree (or international equivalent). MPhil/PhD: A master's qualification or working towards one, or international equivalent. Exceptional cases may be considered for first-class undergraduate degree holders.
structure: MPhil: One-year full-time research degree culminating in a 25,000-word dissertation. PhD: Research project over four years (full-time) culminating in an 80,000-word thesis.

title: Social Policy
summary: The PhD in Social Policy at the University of Bristol focuses on the theory, practice, and implementation of social and public policy research. It addresses social problems through a multidisciplinary approach, combining innovative thinking with diverse methodologies. The program welcomes graduate students from around the world, particularly those interested in topics relevant to national and international policy concerns.
requirements: An upper second-class honours degree and a merit at MSc/MA level (or equivalent experience/qualification). English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: The program duration is up to four years full-time or eight years part-time, with a flexible start date and an emphasis on research relevant to social policy.
careers: Research and teaching in higher education

title: Social Work
summary: The PhD in Social Work at the University of Bristol equips students with the skills to apply social research methods to critically examine contemporary issues in social work practice, policy, and education. Students develop research questions related to their practice experiences and are encouraged to collaborate with relevant organizations to inform social work practice. The program is multidisciplinary and engages with national and international policy.
requirements: An upper second-class honours degree and a merit at MSc/MA level (or equivalent experience/qualification). If English is not your first language, you will need to meet the outlined English language requirements.
structure: The program duration is up to four years full-time or eight years part-time, with new PhD students welcomed year-round, particularly in September and January.

title: Sociology
summary: The PhD in Sociology at the University of Bristol allows students to develop their research expertise on sociological issues within an interdisciplinary environment. Students will work with internationally renowned sociologists and engage in diverse research methodologies, addressing critical social topics. The program emphasizes rigorous conceptual and empirical research that is socially relevant and aims to improve understanding of the social world.
requirements: An upper second-class undergraduate honours degree (or equivalent) and normally a merit at MSc/MA level (or equivalent). If English is not your first language, you will need to meet the outlined English language requirements.
structure: The program duration is up to four years full-time or eight years part-time, with a focus on developing research expertise throughout.

title: Sociotechnical Futures and Digital Methods
summary: The PhD in Sociotechnical Futures and Digital Methods focuses on advanced research in digital methods and the social and political dimensions of technological transformation. It is part of the interdisciplinary South West doctoral pathway and emphasizes the interplay between technology and society. Students will benefit from a supportive research environment and supervision from experts in relevant fields.
requirements: An upper second-class undergraduate honours degree (or equivalent) and normally a merit at MSc/MA level (or equivalent). English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: The programme combines taught and research components. The taught component includes courses on research methods, digital methods, and advanced qualitative and quantitative research methods, while the research component involves undertaking and writing up doctoral research with supervisor support.

title: South West Biosciences Doctoral Training Partnership (BBSRC)
summary: The South West Biosciences Doctoral Training Partnership (SWBio DTP) offers a PhD program led by the University of Bristol in collaboration with other universities and research institutions. It provides interdisciplinary bioscience research training with opportunities for industrial placements and collaborative projects. The program emphasizes a structured training approach in the first year, followed by focused PhD research in subsequent years.
requirements: Check the latest entry requirements on the SWBio DTP website. English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: Year 1 includes two rotation projects and three taught units covering essential skills. Years 2 to 4 focus on the PhD project, with a requirement to submit the thesis within 4 years.

title: Superconductivity
summary: The Superconductivity CDT programme at the University of Bristol focuses on developing knowledge and conducting research in superconductivity, an interdisciplinary field crucial for reducing fossil fuel use, enhancing healthcare, and advancing quantum technologies. The programme emphasizes collaborative learning and includes training in transferable skills, preparing students for both academic and industry careers.
requirements: A master's qualification or equivalent is required. Applicants without a master's may be considered if they hold a first-class undergraduate degree. Non-traditional backgrounds may also be accepted with substantial relevant experience.
structure: The first year includes modules that transition students from undergraduates to independent researchers, combining taught courses, seminars, and research projects. The PhD research project begins at the start of the course and continues throughout.

title: Sustainable Futures
summary: The PhD in Climate Change, Sustainability and Society at the University of Bristol aims to develop researchers who can address the pressing social challenges of sustainability amid global environmental changes. The program emphasizes an interdisciplinary approach, integrating insights from various fields such as economics, law, and psychology to foster collaborative solutions for sustainability.
requirements: A minimum of an upper second class honours degree from a social sciences or law discipline, and a master's qualification with at least a merit (or equivalent) and appropriate research training.
structure: PhD students will follow the structure of the school of their primary supervisor and attend any mandatory units, unless exempted. ESRC/SWDTP students may be required to take additional credits as determined by SWDTP.
careers: Public sector roles in government, national and international agencies
Private sector roles in consultancy or environmental management
Civic sector roles in environmental NGOs and development bodies

title: Technology Enhanced Chemical Synthesis
summary: The Technology Enhanced Chemical Synthesis PhD program at the University of Bristol offers a unique training period that combines research techniques with new technologies and digital methods in chemical synthesis. Students will engage in lab rotations and develop transferable skills, culminating in a research project related to chemical synthesis. The program aims to prepare graduates for careers in both industry and academia.
requirements: An upper second-class honours MSci/MChem degree in chemistry, or international equivalent.
structure: The program begins with an 8-month taught training period in Synthetic and Digital Chemistry, followed by a three-year PhD research project starting in June of the first year.

title: Theatre and Performance
summary: The Theatre and Performance program at the University of Bristol offers PhD and MPhil degrees with a focus on a wide range of subject areas including historical and contemporary theatre practices, performance archives, and immersive theatre. Students can engage in practice-based projects and benefit from the department's strong research capabilities. The program supports both distance learning and on-campus study, providing opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration.

requirements.MPhil: An upper second-class degree or international equivalent.
requirements.PhD: A master's qualification or working towards one, or international equivalent. Exceptional cases may be considered for first-class undergraduate degree holders.

structure: MPhil is a one-year full-time research degree culminating in a 25,000-word dissertation. PhD involves a research project over four years, culminating in an 80,000-word thesis, with options to audit taught units and potential teaching opportunities from the second year.
careers: Research projects in theatre and performance

title: Translation
summary: The Translation program at the University of Bristol offers research opportunities in various fields of translation studies, including audiovisual translation, translation technologies, and literary translation. Students can pursue either an MPhil or PhD, with a focus on developing academic skills and engaging in interdisciplinary research. The program is supported by collaborations with external institutions and provides access to extensive research resources.

requirements.MPhil: An upper second-class degree or international equivalent.
requirements.PhD: A master's qualification or working towards one, or international equivalent. Exceptional cases may be considered for first-class undergraduate degree holders.

structure: MPhil: one-year full-time research degree culminating in a 25,000-word dissertation. PhD: three to four years full-time research project culminating in an 80,000-word thesis.

title: Translational Health Sciences
summary: The Translational Health Sciences program at the University of Bristol focuses on clinical research and applied studies, fostering collaboration between staff and students in high-quality research and clinical settings. It offers PhD, MD, and MSc by research degrees, emphasizing interdisciplinary research in areas such as cardiac surgery, obesity treatment, and Alzheimer's therapies. The program is designed to prepare students for impactful careers in research and academia.
requirements: An upper second-class honours degree (or international equivalent) in biological, biomedical, or related subjects, or a master's degree with a lower second-class honours degree. For an MD, an MBChB is required.
structure: The program duration varies: MScR is up to two years full-time or four years part-time; PhD is up to four years full-time or eight years part-time; MD is up to five years full-time or eight years part-time. PhD by Publication can be completed in up to one year, full or part-time.

title: Veterinary Sciences
summary: The Veterinary Sciences program at the University of Bristol offers postgraduate research opportunities primarily at the Langford campus, focusing on both fundamental and applied veterinary research. Students can pursue either a PhD or an MSc by research, benefiting from a collaborative environment within the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences. The program emphasizes interdisciplinary research and provides training opportunities for prospective students.
requirements: An upper second-class degree (or equivalent qualification) in a relevant subject. English language requirements apply for non-native speakers.
structure: The program duration is up to two years full-time or four years part-time for MScR, and up to four years full-time or eight years part-time for PhD. The research degree is also available via distance learning.
careers: Industry roles in pharmaceuticals and animal feed
Specialist clinical activities in veterinary practices
